title: JB Hi-Fi net profit rises 6.3pc to $136.5m, announces $15.2m share buyback
text:
JB Hi-Fi chief executive Richard Murray is adding small appliances to existing stores to turbocharge sales growth. Photo: Patrick Scala
JB Hi-Fi expects sales growth to accelerate in 2016 as the consumer electronics retailer capitalises on the buoyant housing market by adding small appliances to existing stores.
JB Hi-Fi reported a better-than-expected 6.3 per cent increase in net profit to $136.5 million in 2015 as strong sales of appliances and mobile phones offset weakness in software.
Sales for the 12 months ended June 30 rose 4.8 per cent to $3.65 billion, beating expectations, and chief executive Richard Murray expects sales to grow 5.4 per cent to $3.85 billion in 2016 as the company opens six new stores and converts 16 existing stores to the JB Hi-Fi HOME format, which includes large and small home appliances.
Mr Murray revealed that JB Hi-Fi would introduce small appliances into JB Hi-Fi's existing stores in an attempt to grab a bigger share of the $4.6 billion home appliances market.
JB Hi-Fi's move comes a week after rival Dick Smith unveiled plans to introduce small appliances into 100 Dick Smith stores over the next five months under a sub-brand, ConnectedHome.
Mr Murray said small appliances had been installed in four JB Hi-Fi stores to date, with pleasing results, and another 14 stores would range small appliances by November 2015.
"The rollout of small appliances to our existing store network is a natural progression of our proven home appliances strategy," Mr Murray said.
"The home appliances market in Australia is circa $4.6 billion, larger than many of the other categories JB HI-FI operates in, and presents a significant opportunity for the company as it leverages the strength and trust in the JB HI-FI brand."
"By leveraging our strong heritage in innovation and technology, we see our continued expansion into home appliances and ultimately the connected home as a significant opportunity for JB in the future, he said.
Analysts say JB Hi-Fi's new HOME appliances format is delivering double-digit sales growth, fuelled by the strong housing market, although the cost of converting stores is pushing up the retailer's cost of doing business.
JB Hi-Fi's net profit result beat consensus forecasts of about $131 million and exceeded the company's $127 million-to-$131 million guidance.
Same-store sales growth surged 7.4 per cent in the second half after a weaker first half, taking annual same-store sales growth to 2.9 per cent.
JB Hi-Fi also opened five new stores, taking its network to 187 stores. It expects to open six stores in 2016 and maintained its stated target for 214 stores over time.
JB Hi-Fi increased its final dividend by 2¢ to 31¢ a share, fully franked, taking the full year payout to 90¢ a share vs 84¢. The final dividend is payable September 11.
The retailer also announced it would buy back $15.2 million of its shares to offset the dilutionary impact of shares issued as part of the employee share options scheme.
More to come.
